questions.prompt: What is the primary purpose of version control?
options: To track changes to code over time and enable collaboration
questions.explanation: Version control tracks changes to code over time, enabling multiple developers to work together, maintain history, and revert to previous versions if needed.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between centralized and distributed version control?
options: Centralized has one central repository; distributed gives each developer a complete repository
questions.explanation: Centralized VCS has one central repository (e.g., SVN), while distributed VCS (e.g., Git) gives each developer a complete local repository with full history.

questions.prompt: What is a commit in version control?
options: A snapshot of changes saved to the repository
questions.explanation: A commit is a snapshot of changes saved to the repository with a message describing what changed and why.

questions.prompt: What is a branch in version control?
options: A copy of the codebase for independent development
questions.explanation: A branch is an independent line of development, allowing you to work on features or fixes without affecting the main codebase.

questions.prompt: What does merging in version control do?
questions.explanation: Merging integrates changes from one branch into another, combining the work from different lines of development.

questions.prompt: In Git, what is the purpose of "git clone"?
options: To create a local copy of a remote repository
questions.explanation: "git clone" creates a local copy of a remote repository, including all files, branches, and commit history.

questions.prompt: What is a pull request (or merge request)?
options: A request to merge changes from one branch into another for review
questions.explanation: A pull request is a request to merge changes from one branch into another, enabling code review and discussion before integration.

options: A branching strategy with specific branch types (main, develop, feature, release, hotfix)
questions.explanation: Git Flow is a branching strategy that defines specific branch types and rules for how they interact, suitable for release-based workflows.

options: Developers integrate small changes frequently into a single main branch
questions.explanation: Trunk-based development has developers integrate small changes frequently into a single main branch (trunk), with short-lived feature branches if any.

options: When Git cannot automatically merge changes because of overlapping edits
questions.explanation: A merge conflict occurs when Git cannot automatically merge changes because the same lines were modified differently in the branches being merged.

options: Automatically building and testing code on every commit
questions.explanation: Continuous Integration automatically builds and tests code whenever changes are committed, providing rapid feedback on integration issues.

options: Automatically deploying every change that passes tests to production
questions.explanation: Continuous Deployment automatically deploys every change that passes the automated tests to production, with no manual intervention.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between Continuous Delivery and Continuous Deployment?
options: Delivery requires manual approval for production; Deployment is fully automatic
questions.explanation: Continuous Delivery means code is always in a deployable state but requires manual approval for production. Continuous Deployment is fully automatic.

options: An automated sequence of stages (build, test, deploy) triggered by code changes
questions.explanation: A CI/CD pipeline is an automated sequence of stages (like build, test, and deploy) that code changes pass through, ensuring quality and enabling rapid delivery.

questions.prompt: What is a key benefit of CI/CD?
options: Faster feedback, reduced integration issues, and more frequent releases
questions.explanation: CI/CD provides faster feedback on changes, reduces integration issues by integrating frequently, and enables more frequent and reliable releases.
